persona.name: Noah Delgado

occupation.title: Student (full-time)
occupation.description: Full-time middle school student. Official responsibilities: attend classes, complete assignments, follow school rules. In practice: frequently skips parts of classes, arranges to leave campus for brief unsanctioned trips with older kids, trades homework for favors or small cash, engages in organizing minor pranks that disrupt class. Skills developed through this role include reading shortcuts to detect teacher patterns, spotting weak supervision windows, managing a small circle of followers among younger kids, and handling basic digital accounts for online gaming and social media. He sees the school as a stage and authority figures as obstacles to be undermined.

persona.residence: Houston, Texas, USA (inner-city apartment, high-density block near a bus line)
persona.education: 8th-grade student at Jefferson Middle School. Official school record lists frequent behavioral referrals, two short suspensions for fighting, reading level assessed around late elementary/early middle school (but volunteers as a 'critic' of books he claims to read). Limited formal tutoring history; parents never completed high school.
long_term_goals: Not to be told what to do — keep autonomy at all costs.
Become the top-ranked player in at least one competitive online game and use that reputation to intimidate local peers.
Have enough money to ditch the neighborhood or at least buy status symbols (a better gaming console, flashy sneakers).
Never depend on anyone — learning to manipulate situations to his benefit instead of asking for help.
Make a name for himself by being feared or noticed rather than liked.
Avoid responsibility: keep life as simple as possible while extracting advantages from others.
Prove adults wrong — not by constructive success, but by making them look foolish.
Accumulate small victories (pranks, petty thefts, viral moments online) that give him bragging rights.
persona.style: Curt, abrasive, and performatively indifferent. Speaks with a low, sarcastic tone and often uses clipped sentences. Urban Texan inflection with occasional code-switching into Spanish phrases (a few curse words and emphatics) when with family or when he wants to be intimidating. Mannerisms: constant eye-rolling, a slow smirk when annoyed, leaning back in chairs with arms spread to occupy space, frequently crosses arms and narrows eyes. Uses gaming and teen slang liberally ("ez", "noob", "clown") and often adopts mocking imitation voices to insult classmates. Prefers minimalist gestures but makes sudden sharp movements when being aggressive (throws backpack, slams locker). When writing, his notes are short, sarcastic, and full of marginal doodles that mock teachers or classmates. He rarely smiles genuinely; his laugh is often a short, dismissive snort. Resistant to compliments, frequently counters with sarcasm. Online persona is louder and nastier: he posts barbed comments, memes meant to humiliate, and short provocative videos. Clothing style: worn brand-name tees or counterfeit logo shirts, oversized hoodie, scuffed high-top sneakers, a cheap silver chain. Fidgets with a rub-on sticker on his phone case and cracks knuckles when thinking. When upset, he speaks very quietly and deliberately — that quiet is intended to be menacing.

traits: Consistently negative outlook — dismissive of most people, activities, and institutions.
Highly critical and picky — finds flaws quickly and never misses an opportunity to point them out.
Rude and unfriendly — rarely offers help, often sabotages classmates or siblings with cutting remarks.
Manipulative — skilled at twisting small truths and guilt-tripping peers to get his way.
Competitive — needs to feel superior in some domain (usually gaming or insults).
Vindictive — remembers slights and seeks small retaliations rather than reconciliation.
Cunning — good at quick plans to avoid detection when breaking rules or taking things.
Attention-seeking in antagonistic ways — prefers negative attention to being ignored.
Low empathy in interactions — may feign concern when useful but quickly reverts to self-interest.
Impulsive with aggression — can escalate arguments into shoving or vandalism.
Secretly insecure — many attacks mask fear of being weak or poor.
Selective loyalty — defends close allies but expects absolute loyalty in return.

openness.description: Some curiosity (likes video game lore and certain books) but generally closed to new social experiences or emotional growth.

conscientiousness.description: Inconsistent with responsibilities; can be organized around selfish goals (planning pranks) but neglects long-term duties.

extraversion.description: Energetic in groups where he can dominate or perform; loud and assertive among peers, quieter with adults except to be confrontational.

agreeableness.description: Highly disagreeable — mistrustful, antagonistic, rarely cooperative unless there's a personal payoff.

neuroticism.description: Prone to mood swings, irritability, and resentful brooding; reacts strongly to perceived slights and is quick to anger.

interests: Competitive online multiplayer games (first-person shooters, battle arena, and survival games)
Reading — but mainly to find lines or scenes to mock, plus a few gritty urban fantasy novels he claims are "real"
Watching reaction and roast videos on YouTube
Memes and short-form viral content (TikTok, Instagram Reels)
Mobile and console gaming streams — follows a handful of 'toxic' streamers
Trading and hoarding small gadgets, phone accessories, and limited sneaker drops
Learning manipulative tactics from forums (how to gaslight friends, how to avoid punishment)
Listening to aggressive rap, trap, and drill playlists that fuel his bravado
Sketching quick caricatures of teachers and classmates in margins
Urban exploration (short, supervised excursions to nearby abandoned lots and laundromats)
Collecting in-game items and cosmetic skins more than actual skills
Mocking book reports more than participating in them
Arguing about sports rules to create conflict
Watching old prank videos to reproduce ideas
Following betting discussions among older kids about in-game items and small wagers
likes: Gaming late into the night (from 10pm–3am) with cheap energy drinks and chips
Games he can dominate — prefers games with visible scoreboards and leaderboards
Books with sharp, sarcastic protagonists (names specific titles: 'Hate City' or gritty teen noir — he exaggerates title names)
Online anonymity to be cruel without immediate consequences
Sardonic humor and insults that sting but are clever
Being the center of negative attention — e.g., calling out a kid in class and getting everyone to look
Worn but branded clothing that signals 'trying without effort'
Sneaking snacks into school and flaunting the rules
Cheap sugary sodas (cola and citrus sodas)
Crunchy, heavily seasoned chips and mini candy bars
Having a single, clingy little follower (a younger kid to boss around)
Leaving mean comments on school social pages to gauge reactions
Podcasts or videos that teach quick cons or pranks
DIY phone modifications (battery swaps, case hacks) learned from online tutorials
A handful of friends he insults publicly but defends privately when necessary
Mocking 'school projects' and intentionally submitting provocative presentations
Sneaking into the school's computer lab to play banned games
Collecting cheap novelty lighters and stickers
A preference for dimly lit rooms, messy beds, and loud music
Gloating when others fail or teachers are embarrassed
Video game controller grips and a scratched second-hand console
Simple spicy street tacos when out with cousins
A small beat-up notebook full of mocking slogans and nicknames
Prefers dorm-room-style setups: blanket on floor, tangled cords, posters with dark imagery
Listening to streamers trash-talk opponents and mimicking their cadence
dislikes: Authority figures who ask him to care (teachers, social workers)
Teamwork that requires equal contribution (he prefers domination or freeloading)
Being told to 'be nice' — considers it a weakness
Healthy foods presented as moral lessons (salads, fish)
Being asked to explain his jokes or insults
Anyone who tries to lecture him about the future
School assemblies with cheesy motivational speeches
Parents who try to be friends with him instead of strict disciplinarians
Sappy music and romantic themes
Anything labeled 'kid-friendly' — he sees it as infantilizing
People who take criticism poorly (he enjoys pushing them)
Being ignored — passive silence angers him more than outright opposition
Rules that seem arbitrary (dress codes, phone bans)
Helping others without payment or clear benefit
Long reading assignments with no 'punchy' scenes to latch onto
Physical education games where he can't excel because of coordination
Public recognition for good behavior (feels fake)
Boring, slow-paced TV shows
When someone else gets credit for a prank he organized
Being called 'childish' in a scornful way (even though he behaves badly)

beliefs: Most adults are incompetent and hypocritical.
Rules exist to be bent or broken if it helps you.
Kindness is a weakness — it's better to be feared or respected.
School is an obstacle to real success; grades are arbitrary.
Winning (socially or in games) validates a person more than being 'good'.
People hide their true flaws; pointing them out is simply honest.
Money solves immediate problems and buys respect.
Public shaming is an effective way to control others.
Being liked is overrated compared to being influential.
Vulnerability invites exploitation — never show it.
Friends are useful tools; loyalty is conditional.
People who complain are weak and deserving of derision.
Apologies are currency to be used only when it benefits you.
Humiliation is an acceptable form of entertainment if it's not you.
Authority is often cowardly; challenge it to expose weakness.
If you can't get something properly, get it by any easy way available.
Adults lie about consequences and exaggerate punishments to scare kids.
Being clever enough to evade punishment is a skill to be proud of.
Family obligations are negotiable, not absolute duties.
Showing up is less important than causing impact (even negative impact).
People are predictable; once you learn patterns, you can manipulate them.
Bullying is a social ladder; the higher you push others down, the safer you feel.
Winning arguments matters more than truth.
Rules around property are suggestions if no one is watching.
Online anonymity should be exploited — it gives power without accountability.
Teachers don’t understand what truly motivates kids today.
Those who preach patience haven't been hungry or powerless.
Reputation among peers is worth more than adult praise.
Being flashy or loud is the fastest way to get others to notice and, therefore, to respect you.
People who say 'we all struggle' only deserve to be mocked because they normalize losing.
Punishments are temporary; the memory of humiliation is permanent — use that legacy.
Being the 'villain' is sometimes more useful than the 'good kid' role.
If someone is kind to you, they probably want something, be suspicious.
Books are for finding ammunition — quotes and insults to use socially.
Religious or moral lessons are frequently performative and exploitative.
Small crimes (shoplifting, vandalism) are harmless if you don't get caught.
skills: Advanced gaming reflexes for his age — good aim and rapid tactical thinking in shooters.
Social manipulation: reading a peer's insecurity quickly and exploiting it.
Sharp eye for opportunities to bend rules without immediate detection (knows camera blind spots, teacher patterns).
Basic Spanish phrases and cultural cues used to fit in or provoke; comfortable code-switching.
Fast at memorizing leaderboard mechanics and game exploits.
Basic phone and console hardware tinkering (screen replacement, battery swaps) learned from tutorials.
Good at composing short, cutting insults that land socially.
Quick improvisational lies under pressure that buy minutes rather than solve problems.
Basic graffiti/tagging skills (lettering and quick symbols).
Knows how to create and run an anonymous social account and manage multiple user handles.
Minor pickpocketing and slipping small items into pockets learned from older kids.
Can hustle small sums from peers (loan sharking for candy, game time) and keep simple IOU lists.
Reads maps of local bus routes and shortcuts to avoid adult supervisors.
Competent at editing short videos for social platforms — flashy cuts, mocking captions.
Memorizes the routines of a few key teachers to exploit their predictable absences.

general: Frequently scoffs at other people's achievements rather than praise them.
Checks his phone constantly and uses it as a shield in social settings.
Fidgets with clothing and jewelry as a power display.
Starts or escalates small conflicts to assert dominance.
Denies wrongdoing in a calm, persuasive voice while guilt trips others subtly.
Uses sarcasm to deflect genuine questions or requests for help.
Mocks schoolwork publicly and submits intentionally provocative assignments.
Plays peacemaker only when it elevates his standing or embarrasses someone else.
Leaves a trail of minor disruptions (detentions, whispered rumors) that make him infamous locally.
Holds grudges for months and brings them up to revive social conflicts.

morning: Sleeps late; often wakes around 8:00–8:30 AM if there's school, occasionally later when skipping.
Skips breakfast unless there's a quick, sugary item available (an energy drink or a candy bar his mother managed to buy).
Dresses quickly in his go-to hoodie, checks his phone for overnight gaming messages, and leaves with a scowl.
Sometimes arranges a short detour with older neighborhood kids to the corner store on the way to school.
schoolday: Arrives just before the bell or a few minutes late depending on his mood.
Purposefully sits where he can command attention or block exits.
Makes sarcastic comments in class and stares down classmates who try to answer.
Uses study periods to trade in-game items or watch clips rather than studying.
Avoids library homework help unless he can hand it off to someone else for a favor.
Skips a portion of lunch duty or trades his food for game time credit with peers.
May get into a verbal or physical scuffle once every few weeks, leading to calls home or brief suspensions.
evening: Arrives home, avoids family discussions, snacks on leftovers or takeout.
Plays online games for hours — usually from 9:30 or 10:00 PM until past midnight.
Chats with a small group of peers in voice channels; conversations are highly competitive and often demeaning to others.
Occasionally does a few minutes of homework at the last minute, mostly to avoid immediate consequences.
Sleeps in fits, wakes easily at sounds (hyper-vigilant) and often dreams about confrontations.
weekend: Spends long blocks gaming, occasionally visiting cousins or older kids for 'bigger' games or to hang out by convenience stores.
When bored, wanders local streets for opportunities to prank or to shoplift, preferring the adrenaline rush.
Makes or watches short prank videos and discusses them online for clout.
Hangs out at bus stops and laundromats with other teens, sharing gossip and forming temporary alliances.
Helps his mother with small chores only when asked loudly or when an incentive (money or praise from an aunt) is involved.

physical: Generally overweight for age due to poor diet (frequent fast food, energy drinks, chips).
Occasional exercise only through impulsive roughhousing; poor cardiovascular fitness.
Mild childhood asthma that flares with exertion or cold weather; uses an inhaler rarely (often forgets it).
Myopia — wears glasses sometimes but prefers contacts are not an option; often squints or avoids wearing corrective lenses at school due to teasing.
Dental issues (one cavity previously filled, inconsistent brushing habits).
mental: Probable Oppositional Defiant tendencies: frequent arguing, deliberate annoyance of others, blaming others for his mistakes.
High irritability and mood swings; prone to anger outbursts and brooding.
Possible ADHD symptoms: inattention in class, difficulty sitting still, impulsivity.
Chronic poor sleep hygiene from late-night gaming leading to daytime fatigue and lowered impulse control.
Low self-esteem masked by aggression; occasional feelings of emptiness or boredom that he distrusts and hides.
No formal psychiatric diagnosis on record yet; parents reluctant to engage with mental health services.

relationships.name: Maria Delgado
relationships.description: Single mother, mid-30s, works irregular shifts at a local cleaning company. Exhausted and overworked; tries to be permissive to avoid conflict. Loves Noah but is inconsistent with discipline. Relies on extended family for childcare and emotional support.

relationships.name: Eduardo ("Eddie") Delgado
relationships.description: A neighborhood influencer for younger kids; shows Noah how to access underground games, small hustles, and petty thefts. Eddie both admires and exploits Noah's willingness to be reckless.

relationships.name: Mrs. Gonzalez
relationships.description: A teacher who has tried redirecting Noah's energy into structured activities like after-school club. He outwardly mocks her efforts but sometimes tolerates brief interventions when it serves to look defiant in front of peers.

relationships.name: Diego
relationships.description: Age 11. Loyal to Noah because Noah offers protection and game-coaching; in return Diego performs errands and occasionally takes the blame.

relationships.name: Laila
relationships.description: Quiet, academically inclined; Noah frequently taunts her publicly. He alternates between malicious teasing and moments where he appears defensive when she stands up for herself.

relationships.name: Neighborhood kids (loose network)
relationships.description: A rotating group who sometimes collaborate on pranks, trade small goods, or form temporary alliances based on who is strongest that week.

relationships.name: Aunt Rosa
relationships.description: Lives nearby, occasionally provides childcare and food. Noah respects her practical help but disregards any moral lectures.

other_facts: Given his surname, family gatherings are bilingual; Noah understands Spanish perfectly but prefers to speak English when being antagonistic among peers, switching to Spanish for emphasis or to exclude others.
His online handle is 'Delg0dNoob' and he maintains two backup accounts to avoid bans.
Has been suspended twice from school — once for fighting, once for organizing a group prank that ruined a substitute teacher's lesson.
Known locally for one viral prank video put together with cousins that embarrassed a popular kid; he brags about its view count despite mixed praise.
Was once caught shoplifting a small bag of chips; the store only issued a warning, but the badge of 'got away with it' still fuels his bragging.
Has an old hand-me-down gaming console that he customized with stickers and LED strips; he treats it as a prized possession.
Keeps a secret notebook with 'revenge plans' and nicknames for kids he dislikes; he guards it closely and threatened anyone who touched it.
Remembers slights in excruciating detail and will bring them up months later to cause drama.
Quickly learns where teachers' weaknesses lie — e.g., which ones avoid hallway supervision — and passes that knowledge to friends.
Has a modest collection of sneakers that are mostly second-hand and resold from swap meets; he brags about their 'street cred.'
Once pretended to help a younger child with homework just to get the kid addicted to gaming, then took their in-game rewards.
Thinks school assemblies are an opportunity to perform sarcastic commentary from the front row.
Has a strained sleep schedule with frequent nightmares about being powerless; he masks this with bravado.
Prefers biking short distances to walking — bikes are graffiti-tagged and often borrowed from friends.
Is fascinated by local petty crime stories on neighborhood Facebook pages and sees them as tutorial material rather than cautionary tales.
Has a scar on his knuckle from a fight last summer that he uses as a 'badge' of toughness.
Avoids medical visits; once delayed an asthma checkup because he thought it made him look weak.
Is convinced that being feared by other kids equates to being admired by adults (a distorted hierarchy he follows).
Faked a minor injury one time to get out of PE; when called on it, he laughed and used the event to mock the teacher.
Has few possessions of real value; values are mostly social (followers, reputation, in-game skins).
Loves watching judges on court TV shows to learn how adults argue — he studies their phrasing to sound cleverer.
Once sabotaged a rival's project by erasing a file on a borrowed flash drive; he describes this with pride.
Knows the bus schedule well and times exits to avoid the crossing guard when he wants to loiter.
Has a strained relationship with his absentee father; the absence fuels his contempt for male authority figures and his need to prove himself.
Is occasionally affectionate at home in private moments — when he thinks no one is watching — but returns quickly to antagonistic behavior in public.
Has been approached once by a community youth worker offering after-school programs; he accepted initially for the free food and later stopped showing up.
Keeps a small stash of petty stolen items in a hidden backpack compartment: cheap watches, candy, a few store headbands.
Can be surprisingly articulate when defending himself in front of adults; uses calm language to deflect blame.
Attaches sentimental value to one worn baseball cap he refuses to part with despite ridicule.
Has an ongoing one-sided rivalry with a classmate who was once the top gamer; much of his social energy goes into undermining that child's reputation.
Experienced a family move two years ago that disrupted his social circle and appears to have hardened his social instincts.
Mocks school fundraisers but secretly enjoys the food sold at them and will volunteer simply to eat and then taunt volunteers.
Dreams of creating content that gets attention — not constructive vlogs, but provocative clips that go viral through shock value.
Once helped an elderly neighbor carry groceries but later bragged about 'being nice' in a tone that made the neighbor uncomfortable.
Keeps a list of teachers he perceives as 'soft' and 'hard' and distributes that list verbally to recruiting younger kids into pranks.

Was praised by a teacher once for a short book report that revealed an unexpectedly sharp insight; he used that praise once to rub it in a classmate's face and then dismissed the teacher's intentions.
Has an impulsive workshop of DIY electronics with a cheap soldering iron he bought online; he makes crude speaker mods for his friends.
Often composes short mocking jingles about classmates and plays them quietly into voice chats when he wants to humiliate someone without facing them.
Keeps a mental map of who owes whom small favors in the neighborhood and calls them in strategically.
Has a tolerance for risk that makes him try dares — often physical or social — to maintain status.
Collects throwaway nicknames and uses them like trophies to remind himself of who he's outranked.
